text: this is bailout week in Washington and
on 10 financial markets so the
government's proposed a 700 billion
dollar bailout I personally think it's
going to cost a lot more I think it's
going to cost well over trillion before
it's done but put that aside for a
minute let's just talk about 700 billion
the money will be used to buy the toxic
junk that's on the balance sheet of
these big financial firms in order to
kind of basically both create a price an
understanding of what price might be and
to allow them to take this off their
books rebuild their balance sheet and
get on with business so how should we
think about this number one let's hope
it works because they don't have
anything else there there is no more
possible solutions number two let's be a
little skeptical first of all the
Treasury wants to do this with virtually
no oversight so you really don't know
what kind of deal are going to cut for
the taxpayers the S&L crisis the
government was able to take over failed
SNL's but they were able to sell the
assets in many cases as a profit as the
real estate market came back this is a
different situation these are securities
that may not be worth anything or may
not ever come back for a good long time
and then the question becomes you know
how much of that loss is a taxpayer
absorb and how much of that loss do
these companies absorb now the real
issue is here is if this plan allows the
unfreezing of the financial markets and
if it allows capital money to be
reinvested back in these companies even
after these writedowns because they can
now understand what these companies hold
again which they can't right now then
yeah it'll work but if they can't raise
more capital after the writedowns then
we're right back where we started which
is in a really really bad place
